Award.AwardTitle: Nanoscale solids in strong ultrashort optical pulse

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to provide a comprehensive analysis of interaction of strong ultrashort laser pulses with nanoscale solids, such as dialectic and metal nanofilms. The approach of this research is based on coherent description of electron dynamics within duration of ultrashort (less than 10 fs) laser pulse. Such electron dynamics will be described by systems of nonlinear differential equations, which will be solved numerically.

The proposed research will provide comprehensive theoretical description of ultrashort laser pulse with nanoscale solids and will determine what kind of optical and transport properties of dielectric and metal nanofilm can be controlled by ultrafast optical pulse and within what extent, how the dynamics of dielectric and metal can be probed by the optical pulse, and under what condition the dielectric or metal show reversible behavior.

The proposed research will address both fundamental (understanding the interaction of ultrashort laser pulses with solids) and applied (optical control of electric properties of nanoscale devices with high petahertz frequency, which can be used in nanoscale devices) problems. The broad nature of proposed research activity will encourage graduate students to explore different fields of physics, both fundamental and applied. Introductory and illustrative lecture series on modern nanoscale physics will be given to middle and high school students within the Atlanta, GA area. The PIs will develop undergraduate course on optics and transport of nanoscale systems. The PIs will also organize the Science Olympiad team and Math Club team at two Georgia schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the project, the interaction of ultrashort optical pulses with solids has been studied theoretically. We have shown that such strong and femtosecond-long pulses can both probe and effectively control optical and transport properties of the systems.

For dielectric nanofilms, highly nonlinear but reversible optical responses have been observed. Such responses are driven by the instantaneous optical field. Among them is a high optical polarization and a significant population of the conduction band, which develop at the peak of the pulse and almost disappear after its end.

The unique features were observed for topologically nontrivial materials, such as graphene, silicene, germanene, 3D topological insulators, and transition metal dichalcogenides. For graphene-like materials, which are gapless semimetals, ultrashort optical pulses open a possibility to realize self-referenced interferometry in the reciprocal space without a magnetic field. Unique topological properties of graphene result in chiral textures of interference fringes and singularities in electron distribution in the reciprocal space.

For transition metal dichalcogenide materials, we have demonstrated a fundamental possibility to induce a significant conduction band population and valley polarization during just one optical period of a chiral laser pulse. This is a wideband ultrafast process which is defined by unique topological resonance. This resonance is due to a mutual compensation of the dynamic phase and the non-Abelian Berry phase, which brings about the formation of textures in the reciprocal space with discontinuities. These textures can be directly observed using time-resolved angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy.  The advantage of such induced valley polarization is that it can be written and read out by a pulse consisting of just a single optical oscillation. Such ultrafast induction of the valley polarization promises a wide range of important valleytronics applications, in particular, to PHz-band information processing and storage.
